articles.title: Article I, Section 8, Clause 3 — Commerce Clause

clauses.reference: Congress may regulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among the several States, and with the Indian Tribes.
clauses.interpretation: Current federal posture largely respects interstate scope; risk arises when private, non-commercial conduct is treated as commerce.

clauses.reference: Limits recognized in Lopez and Morrison; non-economic activity beyond Congress’s reach.
clauses.interpretation: Divergence where agencies or states extend ‘commerce’ to private travel or non-economic acts; requires corrective guidance.

articles.title: Article I, Section 8, Clause 7 — Postal Clause

clauses.reference: To establish Post Offices and post Roads.
clauses.interpretation: Core federal authority remains intact; risks appear when state or private rules materially impede postal carriage and routes.

clauses.reference: The powers not delegated to the United States… are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.
clauses.interpretation: Healthy reservation principle exists; divergence where licensing and enforcement frameworks regulate private, non-commercial life as if commerce.

summary.notes: Primary divergences: (1) non-commercial conduct treated as commerce; (2) state licensing regimes functionally burdening private travel. Postal authority largely aligned.
